My suggestion is that you could perhaps rename this method to something like `renameCorruptedFile()` instead? It can still return a boolean value to indicate the success/failure of the operation. Then the assignment to `boolean isRenamed` in `handleCorruptedFile()` will still make sense.
</panel>

**112 :octicon-comment:** (other comment)
</div>

## Update - 25/03/2024:
* `Optional&lt;LocalDate>` is no longer used to represent the `itemExpirationDate` attribute in `Item`. This attribute now only belongs to `Item` classes that are Perishable. Attribute type is now a `LocalDate`.
* `LocalDate.MIN` is used as an "invalid" placeholder value for `itemExpirationDate` at parsing stage. `ItemList` will determine if an item is perishable using this `LocalDate.MIN` value. If a valid `LocalDate` is provided, then the item is deemed to be perishable. 
* `toString()` output has been modified. Items with no expiration date will not have any expiration date field present in their String representation. Likewise, items with no sale price should not see any sale price field in their String representation as well.
* `itemSalePrice` attribute has been moved to `RetailItem`.

</panel>

I agree with the second paragraph! We have to think of a concrete way to display profits for the following:
- Multiple items with the same name (but different UID)
- Items that do not generate revenue (such as operational items)

However, for the first paragraph, can I clarify if you meant `totalUnitsPurchased` and `totalUnitsSold` (for the RetailItem class) ?
`totalRevenue` and `totalCost` are private variables, representing the total revenue and total cost of the user's entire inventory. They are stored in an ItemList class (which I assume will only be instantiated once throughout the lifetime of the program)

Each item having a `totalUnitsPurchased` (and potentially a `totalUnitsSold`) variable gives us the flexibility to come up with methods to calculate `totalRevenue` and `totalCost` in the future.

1. As per discussion just now, there will be a few possible cases during the import process from JSON to `DailyMedicationmanager` (DailyMgr)

2. The core idea is to preserve (past) daily medication data for the future implementation of being able to retrieve taking of medication history (Name, taken, dosage), even if the medication no longer exist in the `MedicationManager` (MedMgr). On that note, DailyMgr will have to refer to MedMgr on a best-effort basis rather than a fail-if-not-found idea. (Remove the assumption that what is on the today list is also on the main list)

3. Possible cases of corruption

Case 1.1: JSON is corrupt and is unable to recover any data but the daily txt file is not corrupt
- In this case, the MedMgr will start from a clean state
- DailyMgr will try to read from the MedMgr on a best-effort basis to get the dosage information, failing which will show "unknown"

Case 1.2: JSON is partially corrupt (able to recover some data) but the daily txt file is not corrupt
- In this case, the JSON will load whatever data that is not corrupt and places a placeholder value for fields not present or corrupt for the MedMgr to load
- DailyMgr will still try to read from the MedMgr on a best-effort basis to get the dosage information, failing which will show "UNKNOWN"

Case 2: Json is not corrupt, Daily txt file is corrupt
- MedMgr loads as per normal
- DailyMgr will try to load in a best-effort basis and still read from the MedMgr thereafter on a best-effort basis to get dosage infromation.


4. Things of things to mention in the User Guide
- a.  That the DailyMgr function "separately" from the MedMgr; That some data (except dosage information) can still be shown even if there is no MedMgr. Put a note over the "list -t today", "take" and "untake" commands to remind users that those are still available even when there is no medication information.
- b. With regards to corrupt data: That the program will still try to load whatever data that is available, but may have fields missing, or start with a clean slate
- c. It will be helpful to inform the user that DailyMgr and MedMgr function mostly separately and independently of each other (and introduce their individual roles in 1-2 sentence), that other side will still work even if one side is missing.
- d. Under the `list -t` command, mention that the `all` and `today` results are separate; that information of one does not affect the information of the other.

5. Mention with comments below whichever part is closed once implemented
</panel>

Static constants are unable to be abstracted. I've considered alternatives but am unable to figure out how to resolve this issue. Advice would be appreciated.

Alternatives:
1) Using an interface for static constants.
    Concerns:
    - If using polymorphism to loop, will require passing in a command instance. This is not ideal as it is a static variable and I do not wish to create instances unnecessarily.
    - Considered bad practice
    
2) Declare all the command details in the `Help` class or a new `CommandDetails` class.
    Concerns:
    - All the variables will need to have different names. i.e. `NEW_COMMAND_KEYWORD`, `EDIT_COMMAND_KEYWORD`. This will still result in the same issue whereby the function is called multiple times but with different variables.

</panel>

```suggestion
switch (selectedCommand) ``{``
        case BYE:
            CommandList.executeBye();
            break;
        case SHOOT:
            CommandList.executeShoot(readArgumentTokens);
            break;
        case PENALTY:
            CommandList.executePenalty();
            break;
        case YES:
            if (MatchStat.getIsMatchEnd()) MatchStat.updateForNewMatch();
            break;
        case NO:
            if (MatchStat.getIsMatchEnd()) CommandList.executeBye();
            break;
```

</div>

Good work in trying to display unrestricted electives MCs!

One issue with this, currently your UE MC remaining calculation relies on matching the courseCode directly with what is in the list which is mostly sufficient.

However specifically for a normal CEG student, the GE pillar courses are quite varied. 

For your method, adding something like "GEC1015" or "USE2310" **will both count under UE**, even though taking **either one of it** should count under "Cultures and Connections (GEC)" pillar. 

If we take both "GEC1015" and "USE2310", one of them will be considered under UE, while the other will be considered under GEC pillar.

Can read the whole GE pillar list from here: https://www.nus.edu.sg/registrar/academic-information-policies/undergraduate-students/general-education/list-of-courses-approved-under-the-ge-pillars

If this is too troublesome, then i think its better to just not calculate the UE's remaining, and just display the graduation list as it is 
</panel>

**4 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)
</div>

Seems like you are instantiating a new `totalRevenue` and `totalCost` for each instance of an item. This would mean that for duplicate items that potentially are of a different batch (i.e. have a different UID) , the `totalRevenue` and `totalCost` will be separate from other items with the same name (correct me if I'm wrong) and will hence start from 0. Users may want to view the profits of items as a whole (meaning if we have three different items called milo, the store owner would sometimes prefer to see the profit for milo in general instead of the profits for each batch of milo).

Lets find a way display the profit margins of the items as a whole rather than for each instance of an item with the same name. Perhaps we can instantiate the values for `totalRevenue` and `totalCost` for future batches of a duplicate item to be the same as the current `totalRevenue` and `totalCost` of the existing item with the same name. Or we can have a method that calculates these values for all batches of the same item if we would like to maintain the profit margins for each batch of item.
</panel>

On account of the suggestion I made to remove the `Health.printNewLine();` statement:

```
public static void calculateBmi() ``{``
        double bmi = Health.weight / (Math.pow(Health.height, 2.0));
        System.out.printf("Your BMI is %.2f", bmi);
        Health.printNewLine();
        printBmiCategory(bmi);
    ``}``
```

Can be refactored as:
```
public static void calculateBmi() ``{``
        double bmi = Health.weight / (Math.pow(Health.height, 2.0));
        System.out.println("Your BMI is %.2f", bmi);
        printBmiCategory(bmi);
    ``}``
```

That should also make the code much tidier. Happy coding!
</panel>

</div>

This approach prioritizes user friendliness, aiming to create a welcoming environment for app users. It adds a personal touch and potentially uplift the user's mood. While it might not directly align with functional requirements, enhancing the user experience contributes to overall satisfaction and engagement with the application.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2113T-T09-2/tp/pull/257#discussion_r1556149968" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**8 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

You have a point. However, the responsibility of the QuoteCommand class is to encapsulate the behavior of generating and executing a quote-related action. Although the logic for generating a random message could be separated into another class, it's still related to the functionality of QuoteCommand and doesn't introduce significant complexity or violation of single responsibility principle. Moreover, separating this logic into another class might lead to unnecessary proliferation of small classes, potentially making the codebase harder to navigate.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2113T-T09-2/tp/pull/257#discussion_r1556150917" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**9 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

The Ui class handles user interface-related functionality. Generating a random message fits within the scope of user interaction, but while it could be argued that generating random messages is not strictly related to user interface tasks, it's still a lightweight operation and doesn't significantly deviate from the overall purpose of the Ui class.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2113T-T09-2/tp/pull/257#discussion_r1556152641" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**10 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

While it's true that the getRandomMessage function is primarily used by QuoteCommand, it's also a form of user interaction that is used elsewhere in the application, when it is provided on startup. Placing it in the Ui class ensures that it's readily available for any future UI-related functionalities that might require similar functionality. Additionally, keeping related functions together can improve code organization and maintainability, as it centralizes related functionalities within a single class.


</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2113T-T09-2/tp/pull/257#discussion_r1556157082" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**11 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

Adhering to the Dependency Inversion Principle, where high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules directly, it's beneficial to maintain loose coupling between components. Although QuoteCommand currently doesn't interact with ItemList, its dependency on ItemList provides flexibility. This promotes loose coupling between components, making the codebase easier to maintain and modify.

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2113T-T09-2/tp/pull/257#discussion_r1556159471" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**12 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

That is true, but the current implementation provides a necessary initialization step for the QuoteCommand. By setting the Ui instance for the QuoteCommand before execution, we ensure that the command has access to the necessary UI functionality to generate and display quotes. This initialization step ensures proper functioning of the QuoteCommand and makes it behaves correctly within the application context. While it may seem like an extra step, it's a part of the command's setup process and does not significantly impact the readability or maintainability of main().
</panel>

**1 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

Yes. The getUserSaveDirection() method prompts the user for input and expects an integer corresponding to the direction to save the penalty. The input is read as a string and then converted into an integer using the convertToShootDirection() method, which checks if the input is within the valid range (0, 1, or 2).
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2113-F15-3/tp/pull/82#discussion_r1545550254" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on own PR)
</div>

The convertToShootDirection() method is designed to parse the argument for the "save" command, which should be an integer within the range (0, 1, or 2). The string passed to this method is expected to be just the argument part of the input, not the full command. In the case of the "save 1" command, only "1" would be passed to convertToShootDirection(). This is handled by the Parser class, which splits the full input string into the command and argument tokens.
</panel>
